journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Temperature stability and fabrication of Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 fibers with Pt core

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing, China

author-notes.corresp: Jinhao Qiu, State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, No. 29 Yudao Street, Nanjing 210016, China. Email: qiu@nuaa.edu.cn

abstract.p: In order to improve the electrical properties of metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fibers at high temperature, Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 piezoelectric ceramics with high Curie temperature were selected. The Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3) O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fibers were successfully fabricated by extrusion Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 powder around a platinum wire. The microstructure and electrical properties of Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 ceramics with different calcining and sintering temperatures were investigated. Compared with the previous metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fibers, the Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 fibers showed lower piezoelectric and dielectric properties (ε33T=1272, k31 = 0.253, and d31 = −120 pC N−1). However, the Curie temperature of Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 ceramics is about 295°C, much higher than that of 0.55Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.45Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3 ceramics (110°C). The Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 fibers can be used at the highest temperature of 150°C, and the temperature stability of Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 fibers is much better than that of 0.55Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.45Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3 fibers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, piezoceramic materials have attracted much attention for sensing, actuation, structural health monitoring, and energy harvesting applications due to their excellent coupling between energy in the mechanical and electrical domains. In research on piezoelectric materials, there is a trend that they can be easily integrated into the host structures (Qiu and Tani, 1995; Qiu et al., 2004; Tani et al., 1998). For this purpose, piezoelectric films, sheets, and fibers have been fabricated in the previous study (Hajjaji et al., 2008; Liu et al., 2009; Luo et al., 2010; Qiu et al., 2003, 2009; Sebald et al., 2006; Zhu et al., 2009).

Piezoelectric fibers with metal core have received special attention in recent years (Hajjaji et al., 2008; Qiu et al., 2003, 2009; Sebald et al., 2006). The advantage of metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fibers (MPFs) is to get less brittle fiber than those without core. Besides, the metal core constitutes one of two electrodes, thus generating a radial electric field. Consequently, large displacements can be reached for limited voltages due to the lateral piezoelectricity (Qiu et al., 2003, 2004; Sebald et al., 2006). MPF is a new type of piezoelectric ceramic device with small size and has great potential to be used as structurally integrated transducers for health monitoring, vibration control, noise control, etc. Application of MPFs for airflow sensors has been proposed (Qiu et al., 2010). Recently, MPFs have been applied to precision drive. The performance of MPFs is easy to be affected by temperature, which results in the increase of measurement error. Therefore, the temperature stability of MPF is important and useful for their practical sensor and actuator applications.

In the previous study, MPFs with compositions of 0.55Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.45Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3 (0.55PNN-0.45PZT) and 0.65Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.35PbTiO3 (0.65 PMN-0.35PT) were successfully fabricated (Hajjaji et al., 2008; Qiu et al., 2003; Sebald et al., 2006). In order to improve the electrical properties at high temperature, piezoelectric ceramics with high Curie temperature were selected in this study. Among all the lead-based relaxor materials, Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3 (PZN) exhibits a high Curie temperature of 140°C (Smolensky, 1970). The addition of such relaxor materials was found to be beneficial for the electrical properties of Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 (PZT)-based ceramics due to the formation of fine and uniform rhombohedral domains along tetragonal ones (Fan and Kim, 2002; Halliyal and Safari, 1994; Yamaguchi, 1999). As one of the candidates, PZN–PZT ceramics have drawn much interest due to their excellent dielectric and piezoelectric properties (Fan and Kim, 2002; Vittayakorn et al., 2004, 2006). It is reported that the composition of 0.3PZN-0.7PZT is close to morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) (Lee et al., 2004). Therefore, the 0.3PZN-0.7PZT ceramic was chosen for this study.

In this study, the microstructure and electrical properties of PZN-PZT ceramics with different calcining and sintering temperatures were investigated. Then, PZN-PZT MPFs have been prepared by extrusion of PZN-PZT powder around a platinum wire (Qiu et al., 2003, 2004; Sebald et al., 2006). The piezoelectric properties of PZN-PZT fibers are compared with that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT and 0.65PMN-0.35PT fibers.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: The 0.3PZN-0.7Pb(Zr0.49Ti0.51)O3 were prepared by conventional solid-state reactions. The appropriate amounts of commercial PbO (99%), Nb2O5 (99.5%), ZrO2 (99%), TiO2 (98%), and ZnO (99.9%) powders were weighed, with a constant PbO excess of 1 wt% to compensate for the lead loss during the calcining and sintering processes, and mixed by ball milling with partially yttrium-stabilized zirconia balls as media in ethanol for 12 h. After drying, the mixture was calcined at 950°C for 4 h in a covered alumina crucible, followed by regrinding through ball milling for 24 h.

After grinding, the powder was divided into two parts. The first part was mixed with 3 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder. Disks with a diameter of 15 mm were prepared by uniaxial pressing at a pressure of 250 MPa. Binder burnout occurred by slow heating to 600°C and holding for 2 h. The disks were sintered in a sealed alumina crucible for 2 h in the temperature range of 1150°C–1250°C.

The second part of powder was mixed with an organic binder solution to make a clayey mixture. The solvent contained polyvinyl butyral used as binder, and additives such as dibutyl phthalate as a plasticizer and myryalim as a dispersant. After mixing, the paste-like mixture was dried at 80°C to form a clayey mixture. The resultant mixture was then extruded into fibers (300 µm in diameter) with a Pt wire (50 µm in diameter) as the metal core at room temperature under a pressure of 20 MPa by an extrusion apparatus (Qiu et al., 2004). In order to minimize the loss of lead due to vaporization, the sintering was carried out in a PbO atmosphere maintained using PbTiO3 as spacer powder. Both the heating rate and the cooling rate were set at 5°C min−1.

The densities of the sintered ceramics were measured using the Archimedes method. The crystalline phases were analyzed using the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) method with Cu-Ka radiation (D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany). The cross-sectional morphology of the ceramics was observed by the scanning emission microscope (SEM; JEOL JSM-6300, Japan). Samples were polarized in 120°C silicon oil bath by applying a direct current (DC) electric field of 3 kV mm−1 for 30 min. Then, the specimens were aged for 24 h followed by the measurements. The dielectric constant (εr) was measured at room temperature on an impedance analyzer (HP 4294A, Agilent, Japan) according to the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Standards Association (IEEE) Standards. The electromechanical coupling factor (k31) and piezoelectric constant (d31) were determined by the same impedance analyzer with the resonance and antiresonance techniques.

sec.title: Characterization and fabrication of the PZN-PZT ceramics
sec.p: Generally, the calcining and sintering temperatures are the main influencing factors on the ceramics electrical properties. In order to improve the final electrical properties of the MPFs, the calcining and sintering temperatures were optimized. The XRD patterns of PZN-PZT ceramic powders calcined at various temperatures are shown in Figure 1. All the powders are a pure phase of perovskite structure, and no detectable traces of the pyrochlore or other impurities are observed. Although the pure perovskite phase has already been obtained at 850°C, ceramic bulks have different piezoelectric properties at different calcining temperatures as shown in Figure 4. The d33 is slightly higher at 950°C compared with other calcining temperatures. The effects of calcining temperature on piezoelectric properties of ceramics were investigated in the previous study (Luo et al., 2010). It is reported that different calcining temperatures lead to different particle sizes after milling. The ceramic powders with different particle sizes have different sintering activities during sintering process. Sintering process is affected by particle size; thus, the samples have different piezoelectric properties.

caption.p: XRD patterns of PZN-PZT ceramic powders calcined at various temperatures: (a) 850°C, (b) 900°C, and (c) 950°C.
XRD: X-ray powder diffraction; PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the XRD patterns of PZN-PZT ceramics calcined at 950°C and sintered at various temperatures. Pure phase of perovskite structure is important to the piezoelectric properties, since the pyrochlore phase is highly detrimental to dielectric and piezoelectric properties. All the ceramics exhibit the characteristics of pure perovskite phase as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: XRD patterns of PZN-PZT ceramics calcined at 950°C and sintered at various temperatures: (a) 1150°C, (b) 1175°C, (c) 1200°C, (d) 1225°C, and (e) 1250°C.
XRD: X-ray powder diffraction; PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3.

sec.p: The microstructures of fracture surfaces of PZN-PZT bulk ceramic with various sintering temperatures are shown in Figure 3. There are a few pores in the ceramics sintered at 1150°C. The grain sizes increase slightly with increasing sintering temperature. The ceramics have almost fully dense microstructures and uniform grain size when sintered at 1225°C. However, with the further increase of sintering temperature, there are a few pores and nonuniform grains in the ceramics.

caption.p: SEM micrographs of PZN-PZT bulk ceramic with sintering temperature of (a) 1150°C, (b) 1175°C, (c) 1200°C, (d) 1225°C, (e) 1250°C, and fiber with sintering temperature of (f) 1225°C.
SEM: scanning emission microscope; PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3.

sec.p: Figure 4 shows the piezoelectric constant (d33) of PZN-PZT specimens with different calcining and sintering temperatures. The d33 increases with increasing temperature. Then, a maximum value of d33 is observed at a sintering temperature of 1225°C. With further increasing sintering temperature, the d33 decreases rapidly. As shown in Figure 3, the ceramics have almost fully dense microstructures and uniform grain size when sintered at 1225°C compared with other sintering temperatures. The piezoelectric performance of the ceramics is better than others. It can be concluded that the calcining temperature is 950°C and the sintering temperature is 1225°C.

caption.p: Piezoelectric constant of PZN-PZT ceramic with different calcining and sintering temperatures.

sec.p: Since pure phase of perovskite structure and microstructure are important to the piezoelectric properties, fibers should be compared with bulk ceramic. Figure 5 shows the XRD patterns of bulk ceramic and fiber after sintering at 1225°C. Both bulk ceramic and fiber show a pure phase of perovskite structure. The fracture microstructure of PZN-PZT bulk ceramic and fiber is given in Figure 3(d) and (f), respectively. The comparison between Figure 3(d) and (f) indicates that there is no remarkable difference in microstructure between bulk ceramic and fiber. Uniform grains were observed with the grain size in the range of 1–3 µm, as shown in Figure 3(d) and (f).

caption.p: XRD patterns of (a) PZN-PZT bulk ceramic and (b) fiber sintered at 1225°C.
XRD: X-ray powder diffraction; PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3.

sec.title: Piezoelectric and dielectric properties of MPFs
sec.p: In order to compare the properties of PZN-PZT fibers with the fibers fabricated previously, the properties of the fibers were measured by testing the resonance frequency and antiresonance frequency (Sebald et al., 2005). All the results are summarized in Table 1.

caption.p: Properties of PZN-PZT MPFs and 0.55PNN-0.45PZT MPFs.

fn.p: PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3; 0.55PNN-0.45PZT: 0.55Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.45Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3; MPF: metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fiber.

sec.p: As shown in Table 1, the electrical properties of PZN-PZT fibers were obtained from 10 samples. The properties of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers are taken from the previous study by Sebald et al. (2006).

Compared with the bulk ceramic, the piezoelectric properties of the fibers are lower than that of bulk ceramic. There is a large performance loss by the effect of polarization on the material’s properties. Due to the radial electric field, the field is far higher at the center of the fiber than on the edge, thus inducing discrepancies in the poling process. In the previous study, it was found that polarization was the cause of the differences in properties between the fibers and the bulk ceramics (Hajjaji et al., 2008; Sebald et al., 2006).

The d31 of PZN-PZT fibers is lower than that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers, about 83% of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers. However, the k31 is slightly higher than 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers. Even more important, the Curie temperature of PZN-PZT is 295°C, much higher than that of the 0.55PNN-0.45PZT (110°C).

The εr of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT is much higher than that of PZN-PZT at room temperature. When the temperature is increased to 100°C, the εr of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT is three times of the value at room temperature, but the εr of PZN-PZT changes little as shown in Figure 6. In the previous study, the 0.55PNN-0.45PZT and 0.65PMN-0.35PT fibers with metal core were successfully fabricated. Among the three kinds of piezoelectric ceramics, the Curie temperature of PZN-PZT is highest (Figure 6). The Curie temperature of PZN-PZT is about 295°C, which is far higher than that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT, leading to the improvement of the temperature stability.

caption.p: Temperature dependence of the dielectric constant at 1 kHz for (a) 0.55PNN-0.45PZT, (b) 0.65PMN-0.35PT, and (c) PZN-PZT.

sec.p: The properties of piezoelectric elements are more or less temperature dependent. If a piezoelectric element is heated to its Curie point, the element becomes completely depolarized. The k31 and d31 of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT and PZN-PZT fibers with temperature stability are illustrated in Figure 7. When the temperature is closed to 100°C, both k31 and d31 of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers decrease rapidly.

caption.p: Temperature dependence of k31 and d31 for MPFs.
MPF: metal-core piezoelectric ceramic fiber; PZN-PZT: Pb(Zn1/3Nb2/3)O3–Pb(Zr,Ti)O3; 0.55PNN-0.45PZT: 0.55Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3–0.45Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3.

sec.p: The temperature stability of MPFs should be improved for application. Compared with the 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers, the temperature stability of PZN-PZT fibers is much better as shown in Figure 7. The electromechanical coupling factor of PZN-PZT fibers keeps at 0.25, even the temperature increased to 200°C. When the temperature is increased from room temperature to 200°C, the variation of k31 and d31 of PZN-PZT fibers is relatively small. The k31 decreases slightly, but the d31 increases slightly. A piezoelectric element can therefore function for long period without significantly depolarization only at temperatures well below the Curie point. A safe operating temperature would normally be about halfway between 0°C and the Curie point (Randeraat and Setterington, 1974). The 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers should be used under the temperature of 55°C, and the PZN-PZT fibers can be used at the highest temperature of 150°C. So the temperature stability of PZN-PZT fibers is much better than that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, PZN-PZT MPFs were fabricated, and the properties were evaluated and compared with that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT MPFs. The microstructure and electrical behavior of PZN-PZT ceramics with different calcining and sintering temperatures were investigated. The optimal calcining and sintering temperatures were 950°C and 1225°C, respectively. The piezoelectric property values were ε33T=1272, k31 = 0.253, and d31 = −120 pC N−1. Compared with the previous MPFs, the PZN-PZT fibers showed lower piezoelectric and dielectric properties than that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers. However, the Curie temperature of PZN-PZT ceramics is about 295°C, which is far higher than 110°C of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT ceramics. The PZN-PZT fibers can be used at the highest temperature of 150°C, and the temperature stability of PZN-PZT fibers is much better than that of 0.55PNN-0.45PZT fibers.
